name: Chicken Adobo
description: A classic Filipino dish of chicken simmered in soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, and peppercorns.
instructions: Combine all ingredients in a pot and simmer until chicken is tender.
Optional: Pan-fry the chicken after simmering for a crispy texture.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Sinigang na Baboy
description: A savory and sour soup made with pork, tamarind broth, and various vegetables.
instructions: Boil pork in water until tender.
Add onions, tomatoes, and radish. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in tamarind mix and add water spinach. Serve hot.

name: Beef Kare-Kare
description: A rich and savory Filipino stew with a thick peanut sauce, oxtail, and vegetables.
instructions: Boil oxtail until tender.
In a new pot, whisk in ground rice and peanut butter with the broth until thick.
Add oxtail and vegetables. Serve with bagoong.

name: Pork Sisig
description: A sizzling, savory dish made from chopped pig's face and belly, seasoned with calamansi and chili.
instructions: Boil pork parts until tender, then grill or broil until crispy.
Chop finely and sauté with onions and chili.
Serve on a sizzling plate, top with a raw egg, and squeeze calamansi over.

name: Lechon Kawali
description: Deep-fried pork belly with a perfectly crispy skin and juicy, tender meat.
instructions: Simmer pork belly in water with salt, bay leaves, and peppercorns until tender.
Air dry or pat dry completely.
Deep fry in hot oil until the skin is golden brown and crispy.

name: Crispy Pata
description: A whole pork leg boiled until tender and then deep-fried until golden and crunchy.
instructions: Boil pork leg with seasonings until very tender.
Drain and dry thoroughly, preferably chilling it for a few hours.
Deep fry until skin is blistered and crispy.

name: Bicol Express
description: A Bicol specialty of spicy and creamy stew made of pork, chili peppers, and coconut milk.
instructions: Sauté garlic, then add pork and cook until lightly browned.
Add shrimp paste and chilies, cook for a minute.
Pour in coconut milk, bring to a simmer, and cook until pork is tender and sauce is thick.

name: Pancit Palabok
description: A noodle dish with a rich shrimp sauce, topped with shrimp, crushed chicharon, and hard-boiled eggs.
instructions: Cook noodles as per package instructions.
Make the sauce by sautéing pork and shrimp, then simmering with shrimp broth and annatto.
Pour sauce over noodles and add all toppings.

name: Lumpia Shanghai
description: Crispy, deep-fried spring rolls filled with a savory mixture of ground pork and vegetables.
ingredients: Sweet and sour sauce for dipping
instructions: Mix ground pork with all the minced vegetables and seasonings.
Wrap a small amount of the mixture in a lumpia wrapper.
Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.

name: Bulalo
description: A light-colored soup made by cooking beef shanks and bone marrow until the fat has melted into the broth.
ingredients: 1 kg beef shanks with bone marrow
2 corns on the cob, cut into 3 parts
instructions: Boil beef shanks in a large pot of water for several hours until the meat is falling off the bone.
Add corn, onions, and cabbage.
Season with fish sauce and serve piping hot.

name: Tapsilog
description: A tapa with egg as tapsilog shorten it, is popular breakfast meal containing beef tapa, fried rice (sinangag), and a fried egg (itlog) in the philippines.
instructions: Fry the beef tapa until cooked to your liking.
Fry an egg sunny-side up.
Serve everything on a plate with hot garlic rice and a side of vinegar dip.

name: Chicken Inasal
description: A unique variant of grilled chicken from Bacolod, marinated in a mixture of calamansi, pepper, and annatto.
ingredients: 1 whole chicken, cut into serving pieces
instructions: Marinate chicken in the mixture for at least 4 hours.
Grill over hot coals while basting with annatto oil.
Serve with rice and a dipping sauce of soy sauce, vinegar, and calamansi.

name: Laing
description: A spicy Bicolano dish of shredded taro leaves cooked in thick coconut milk with shrimp paste and red chili.
instructions: Simmer pork/shrimp in coconut milk with shrimp paste and chili.
Add the dried taro leaves and continue to simmer without stirring until leaves are soft.
Stir gently and cook until the sauce is very thick and oily.

name: Dinuguan
description: A savory stew of pork offal simmered in a rich, dark gravy of pig blood stew, garlic, chili, and vinegar.  best during rainy days.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion, then add pork and cook until brown.
Pour in vinegar and simmer without stirring for a few minutes.
Stir in the pig's blood and cook until the sauce thickens. Add green chili before serving.

name: Pinakbet
description: An indigenous Filipino dish from the northern regions, made from mixed vegetables sautéed in fish or shrimp sauce.Also bealive give long life(beacause its healty)
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and pork/shrimp.
Add the shrimp paste and cook for a minute.
Add the hard vegetables (squash) first, then the rest, and simmer until tender-crisp.

name: Arroz Caldo
description: A hearty Filipino rice porridge (congee) cooked with chicken, ginger, and garnished with toasted garlic. Best dish when in rainy days and when yopu are sick
instructions: Sauté ginger and chicken in a pot.
Add rice and stir-fry for a minute.
Pour in chicken broth, bring to a boil, then simmer until rice is soft and the porridge is thick. Garnish before serving.

name: Bistek Tagalog
description: Filipino beef steak made of thin slices of beef marinated, cured and braised in soy sauce and calamansi juice.
instructions: Marinate beef in soy sauce, calamansi juice, and pepper for at least an hour.
Pan-fry the beef slices until brown. Set aside.
In the same pan, sauté onion rings until soft, then add back the beef and the marinade. Simmer for a few minutes.

name: Kaldereta Manok
description: A classic Filipino meat stew, a chicken dish , cooked in a tomato-based sauce with liver paste.
ingredients: 1 kg beef or chicken, adobo choped
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions, then brown the meat.
Add tomato sauce and water, then simmer until meat is tender.
Add liver paste, vegetables, and olives. Cook until vegetables are tender.

name: Mechado
description: A braised beef dish cooked in a tomato sauce with a strip of pork fat inserted into the meat.
instructions: Lard the beef with pork fat.
Brown the beef in a pan.
Add tomato sauce, soy sauce, and calamansi. Simmer until beef is tender.
Add potatoes and carrots and cook until done.

name: Ginataang Manok
description: A Filipino chicken stew made from chicken in coconut milk with green papaya and leafy vegetables.
instructions: Sauté ginger, garlic, and onion. Add chicken and cook until color changes.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
Add papaya and chili, and cook until chicken and papaya are tender.

name: Caldereta Kambing
description: A Filipino Goat stew made from Goat meat in a liver spread with vinegar, tomato sauce, onions and carrots.
ingredients: 2 kg cubed Goat Meat, cut up
Thai Chili Pepper or Birds eye chili
instructions: Soak the meat in vinegar to remove the gamey taste and speed up cook time. But don't marinate for too long, as vinegar is a strong acid and can dry out the meat, making it tough.
Aside from marinating in vinegar, you can boil the goat meat in pandan leaves to remove the smell.
You can also soak the goat meat in buttermilk or milk for 1 to 2 hours. It has the same effects as vinegar.
Cooking time depends on the goat's age; the older the goat, the longer it cooks. The best way to tell that it is done is when the skin is soft and gelatinous

name: Kalderobo
description: A Mix of  caldereta and adobo.is a delightful Filipino dish that seamlessly blends the hot and savory elements of kaldereta, the tangy goodness of adobo and the additional creaminess of peanut butter and coconut milk. This fusion creates a unique and harmonious medley of flavours that is sure to satisfy your taste buds.
ingredients: Thai Chili Pepper or Birds eye chili
instructions: In a bowl, combine all marinade ingredients together. Add the pork belly to the marinade, making sure it is fully coated. Let it marinate for at least 2 hours.
Heat oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Remove the pork from the marinade and sear until browned on all sides. Set aside.
In the same pot, sauté the minced garlic and chopped onions until fragrant. Add the sliced capsicums and cook for a few minutes until slightly softened.
Return the seared pork to the pot with the vegetables. Pour in the marinade, coconut milk, and pork stock. Stir in the peanut butter, liver spread and chillies.

Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot and let it simmer for about 1 1/2 hours or until the pork is tender and the flavours have melded together. Stir occasionally and adjust the seasoning if needed.
After the pork has simmered, add the carrots, potatoes, and capsicum to the pot. Continue simmering until the vegetables are cooked through and tender.

name: pouchero
description: A well-loved Filipino stew, a type of stew composed of chicken, sausage, vegetables, plantains, and tomatoes. The harmonious collaboration of different flavors makes this dish extra special.
instructions: Heat cooking oil in a cooking pot.
Sauté garlic, onions, and tomatoes
Add pork and cook until the color turns light brown.
Put-in fish sauce, whole pepper corn, and tomato sauce. Stir.
Add water and let boil. Simmer until pork is tender (about 30 to 40 minutes).
Put-in potato, plantain, and chick peas. Cook for 5 to 7 minutes.
Add cabbage and long green beans. Cook for 5 minutes.
Stir-in the bok choy. Cover the pot and turn off the heat.
Let the residual heat cook the bok choy (about 5 minutes).
Transfer to a serving plate and serve
Share and enjoy!

name: Goto Batangas
description: also known as arroz caldo con goto, is a Filipino rice and beef tripe gruel cooked with ginger and garnished with toasted garlic, scallions, black pepper, and chicharon. It is usually served with calamansi, soy sauce, or fish sauce (patis) as condiments, as well as a hard-boiled egg. It is a type of lugaw.
ingredients: 1 ½ lbs ox tripe cut into serving pieces
17 ounces beef stock about 500 ml or 1 piece beef cube (bouillon) diluted in 17 ounces of water
¾ cup chicharon pork rinds, crushed
instructions: In a pot, heat the cooking oil then sauté the garlic, onion, and ginger
Dash-in some ground black pepper
Add the ox tripe and cook for 2 minutes
Pour-in the fish sauce and water then simmer until the ox tripe is tender (you may use a pressure cooker for faster results)
Add the uncooked rice and stir
Pour-in the beef broth and bring to a boil.
Stir occasionally until the rice reaches the desired consistency (about 40 minutes). Add water as needed
Put-in the hard boiled eggs then stir.
Add the safflower for additional color and aroma.
Serve hot with minced green onions, crushed chicharon, and lemon. Share and Enjoy!
